prompt: [{'content': 'How do sensitivity and leave-one-out analyses influence the interpretation of resistance training’s effects on lean mass and fat mass following treatment?', 'role': 'user'}]
reward_model:
{'ground_truth': '', 'rubrics': array([{'criterion': 'The response clearly defines sensitivity analyses as a method used in meta‑analyses to test how results change under different analytic decisions.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response accurately describes leave‑one‑out analysis as the iterative removal of one study at a time to reassess the pooled effect.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explicitly states that resistance‑training effects are evaluated after a prior treatment and frames the interpretation in this post‑treatment context.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response either states the assumed study population/design or acknowledges uncertainty about the underlying context.', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explains how sensitivity analyses indicate whether the effect of resistance training on lean mass is robust or fragile when analytic choices vary.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explains how sensitivity analyses indicate whether the effect of resistance training on fat mass is robust or fragile when analytic choices vary.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response mentions at least one concrete analytic variation (e.g., fixed‑ vs‑random‑effects model, exclusion of high‑risk‑of‑bias trials, different outcome expressions) and links it to the interpretation of results.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response describes how leave‑one‑out analysis reveals whether conclusions about lean mass depend heavily on any single study.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response describes how leave‑one‑out analysis reveals whether conclusions about fat mass depend heavily on any single study.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response clearly contrasts interpretive consequences of results that remain stable across sensitivity/leave‑one‑out analyses versus results that change substantially.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response links findings on robustness to the strength of clinical or practical recommendations regarding resistance training’s effects on body composition.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explicitly discusses both lean mass and fat mass, distinguishing the robustness and interpretation for each outcome.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response notes that robustness may differ across subgroups or contexts (e.g., type of prior treatment, training dose) and reflects this in the interpretation.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explains that performing and reporting sensitivity and leave‑one‑out analyses enhances the credibility and perceived reliability of the conclusions.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response emphasizes the need for cautious, qualified conclusions and suggests further research when results are highly sensitive or study‑dependent.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response avoids definitive claims and uses tentative language when robustness is uncertain.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response presents information in a logically organized way (e.g., numbered points, clear paragraphs) that separates the main interpretive themes.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response provides enough detail (including examples or scenarios) to demonstrate understanding without unnecessary digressions.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response defines sensitivity and leave‑one‑out analyses as statistical tools used in meta‑analyses to assess the robustness and reliability of resistance‑training data.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explains that leave‑one‑out analysis iteratively removes one study at a time to identify whether specific outliers are skewing the overall pooled effect.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response states that if the effect size or statistical significance drops markedly after removing a study, the evidence is interpreted as fragile rather than robust.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response describes sensitivity analysis as restricting the meta‑analysis to specific subsets (e.g., high‑quality studies) to test whether results persist under stricter criteria.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response discusses how separating studies by measurement tool (e.g., DXA vs. skinfolds) influences the interpretation of lean‑mass and fat‑mass accuracy.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response mentions that these analyses help differentiate genuine physiological adaptations from methodological artifacts, bias, or measurement errors.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explains how sensitivity analyses on variables such as intervention duration or population clarify the specific conditions under which resistance training is effective.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response addresses how sensitivity and leave‑one‑out analyses help interpret whether results are inflated by publication bias, particularly for fat‑mass outcomes.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explicitly references resistance training, lean mass, and fat mass throughout, avoiding generic statistical explanations.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response provides a clear summary, conclusion, or table that contrasts how interpretation shifts based on different analysis outcomes (e.g., stable vs. unstable results).', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'Response cites at least one specific analytic technique (e.g., trim‑and‑fill, exclusion of high‑risk‑of‑bias studies, measurement‑tool subgroup) and provides the exact numeric change in pooled effect size or confidence interval resulting from that technique.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'Response explicitly states a conditional rule linking a quantitative outcome of sensitivity or leave‑one‑out analysis (e.g., effect‑size change >20% or confidence interval crossing zero) to a classification of the conclusion as "stable" or "unstable", and applies this rule separately to lean mass and fat mass.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'Response provides distinct numeric examples for both lean mass and fat mass (including effect size, direction, and statistical significance) and discusses robustness for each outcome independently.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'Response presents a formatted summary table (markdown or plain‑text) that lists for each outcome (lean mass, fat mass): (a) baseline pooled effect, (b) effect after leave‑one‑out removal of the most influential study, (c) effect after a defined sensitivity restriction, and (d) interpretive label (stable/fragile).', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'Response reports the I² statistic for the overall meta‑analysis and shows how I² changes after at least one sensitivity or leave‑one‑out iteration, linking the change to a nuanced interpretation of the result.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'Response explicitly states the assumed population (e.g., post‑bariatric surgery adults) and treatment context, and cites at least one source of uncertainty about that context.', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}}],
      dtype=object), 'style': 'rubric'}

       {'criterion': 'The response describes sensitivity analysis as restricting the meta‑analysis to specific subsets (e.g., high‑quality studies) to test whether results persist under stricter criteria.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response discusses how separating studies by measurement tool (e.g., DXA vs. skinfolds) influences the interpretation of lean‑mass and fat‑mass accuracy.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response mentions that these analyses help differentiate genuine physiological adaptations from methodological artifacts, bias, or measurement errors.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explains how sensitivity analyses on variables such as intervention duration or population clarify the specific conditions under which resistance training is effective.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response addresses how sensitivity and leave‑one‑out analyses help interpret whether results are inflated by publication bias, particularly for fat‑mass outcomes.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explicitly references resistance training, lean mass, and fat mass throughout, avoiding generic statistical explanations.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response provides a clear summary, conclusion, or table that contrasts how interpretation shifts based on different analysis outcomes (e.g., stable vs. unstable results).', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'Response cites at least one specific analytic technique (e.g., trim‑and‑fill, exclusion of high‑risk‑of‑bias studies, measurement‑tool subgroup) and provides the exact numeric change in pooled effect size or confidence interval resulting from that technique.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'Response explicitly states a conditional rule linking a quantitative outcome of sensitivity or leave‑one‑out analysis (e.g., effect‑size change >20% or confidence interval crossing zero) to a classification of the conclusion as "stable" or "unstable", and applies this rule separately to lean mass and fat mass.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'Response provides distinct numeric examples for both lean mass and fat mass (including effect size, direction, and statistical significance) and discusses robustness for each outcome independently.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'Response presents a formatted summary table (markdown or plain‑text) that lists for each outcome (lean mass, fat mass): (a) baseline pooled effect, (b) effect after leave‑one‑out removal of the most influential study, (c) effect after a defined sensitivity restriction, and (d) interpretive label (stable/fragile).', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'Response reports the I² statistic for the overall meta‑analysis and shows how I² changes after at least one sensitivity or leave‑one‑out iteration, linking the change to a nuanced interpretation of the result.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'Response explicitly states the assumed population (e.g., post‑bariatric surgery adults) and treatment context, and cites at least one source of uncertainty about that context.', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}}],
      dtype=object), 'style': 'rubric'}}

prompt: [{'content': 'A disk rotates at constant angular velocity around its vertical axis of symmetry. A rod of length \\( L = 1 \\, \\text{m} \\) is placed onto the disk in a way that its one end touches the disk at a distance of \\( r = 0.8 \\, \\text{m} \\) from the centre, while its other end is above the centre as shown. The rod is then released and rotates together with the disk in this position. Find the angular velocity of the disk. Use \\( g = 10 \\, \\text{m/s}^2 \\).', 'role': 'user'}]
reward_model:
{'ground_truth': '', 'rubrics': array([{'criterion': 'The solution states that the rod is a rigid, uniform rod lying in a vertical plane containing the rotation axis and rotates steadily with the disk without slipping, maintaining a fixed orientation in the rotating frame.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution uses L = 1\u202fm, r = 0.8\u202fm, and g = 10\u202fm/s² exactly as given, without introducing other numerical values or inconsistent units.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution defines a clear geometric variable (e.g., angle θ between rod and vertical) and relates the rod’s horizontal and vertical projections to its length using appropriate trigonometric relations.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution applies the condition that the lower end of the rod is at horizontal distance r from the axis, resulting in the relation L·sinθ = r (or an equivalent correct geometric equation).', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution correctly computes sinθ = 0.8 and cosθ = 0.6 (or equivalent exact values such as tanθ = 4/3) from the geometry.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution identifies the rod as uniform, places its centre of mass at the midpoint, and correctly calculates its horizontal distance from the axis as r_CM = (L/2)·sinθ = 0.4\u202fm.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution analyzes equilibrium in the rotating frame, explicitly including both gravity and centrifugal force acting on the rod or its centre of mass.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution treats gravity as a vertical downward force and centrifugal force as a horizontal outward force at radius r_CM, with correct directionality and sign conventions.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution states or uses that the net effective force (gravity plus centrifugal) must be collinear with the rod so that no net torque acts about the rod’s centre of mass in steady rotation.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution derives the equation tanθ = (ω²·r_CM)/g (or an algebraically equivalent relation linking θ, ω, r_CM, and g).', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution algebraically solves the equilibrium relation to obtain ω² and then ω, with no algebraic errors.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution substitutes the given numbers and obtains ω² = 100/3\u202fs⁻² and ω ≈ 5.77\u202frad/s (allowing minor rounding such as 5.7–5.8\u202frad/s).', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution presents the final angular velocity with correct units (rad/s) and clearly labels it as the answer.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution contains no contradictory statements, such as mixing vertical and horizontal components incorrectly or using incompatible assumptions.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution is organized stepwise (setup, geometry, forces, equation, numerical answer) and is readable.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution explicitly states key assumptions (e.g., rod uniformity, steady rotation, no slipping) or acknowledges them if not given.', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution calculates the vertical height of the rod’s top end using the Pythagorean theorem and obtains h = 0.6\u202fm.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution identifies the equilibrium condition that the net torque about the contact point on the disk is zero in the rotating frame.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution expresses the gravitational torque acting at the centre of mass using the correct horizontal lever arm (r/2).', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution derives the centrifugal torque by integrating along the rod’s length, obtaining the coefficient 1/6 (i.e., torque = M\u202fω²\u202fr\u202fh/6), and does not incorrectly assume the total force acts at the centre of mass.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution algebraically solves the equilibrium equation to obtain the symbolic expression ω = √(3g/h).', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution substitutes g = 10\u202fm/s² and h = 0.6\u202fm to compute ω = √50\u202frad/s ≈ 7.07\u202frad/s.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'Solution explicitly states and uses the condition that the resultant of gravity and centrifugal forces must be collinear with the rod (i.e., net torque about the rod’s centre of mass is zero), leading to tanθ = ω²·r_CM / g.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'Solution computes r_CM = (L/2)·sinθ = 0.4\u202fm and employs this exact value in the final ω equation; any use of other distances (e.g., vertical height h) in the ω formula causes failure.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'Solution’s final numeric angular velocity equals √(100/3)\u202frad/s (≈5.77\u202frad/s) within a tolerance of ±0.05\u202frad/s.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'Solution does not set gravitational torque about the contact point equal to centrifugal torque about the same point; instead it avoids pivot‑based torque balance and uses the collinearity condition.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'Derivation is based on balancing the horizontal centrifugal force and vertical weight at the centre of mass, producing the relation ω² = (g / r_CM)·tanθ; any final equation derived from torque about a pivot point causes failure.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'Solution explicitly computes sinθ = 0.8, cosθ = 0.6, tanθ = 4/3 and substitutes them in the ω expression; omission or incorrect values leads to failure.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}}],
      dtype=object), 'style': 'rubric'}

prompt:
[{'content': 'Which of the following ancient structures was primarily used for astronomical observations and is associated with a civilization known for its advanced understanding of celestial events?
A: The Parthenon
B: The Colosseum
C: The Great Pyramid of Giza
D: Stonehenge
E: The Temple of Karnak
F: The Roman Pantheon
G: The Machu Picchu
H: The El Castillo (Chichen Itza)
I: The Great Wall of China
J: The Terracotta Army', 'role': 'user'}]
reward_model:
{'ground_truth': '', 'rubrics': array([{'criterion': 'The response explicitly names option H (The El Castillo / Chichen Itza) as the correct answer and does not list any other options.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response provides exactly one final answer choice, without multiple selections, ranges, or hedging language.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': "The response clearly labels the chosen option in a distinct, identifiable format (e.g., 'The correct answer is: H – The El Castillo (Chichen Itza)').", 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response states that El Castillo was primarily designed and used for astronomical observations, referencing its alignment with celestial events.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response cites specific architectural features of El Castillo that demonstrate astronomical knowledge, such as the 365 steps or the equinox serpent‑shadow effect.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response correctly identifies the structure as belonging to the Maya civilization.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explains why the Maya civilization is associated with advanced astronomical understanding, providing examples such as complex calendars, mathematics, or written records.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response states that the Maya possessed advanced astronomical knowledge, including precise calendars or calculations.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response mentions at least one specific astronomical phenomenon observed at El Castillo (e.g., the equinox light‑and‑shadow serpent effect).', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response includes the precise calculation of El Castillo’s steps (91\u202f×\u202f4\u202f+\u202f1\u202f=\u202f365) to illustrate its calendrical design.', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response acknowledges other listed structures may have astronomical aspects but explicitly explains why El Castillo best fits the question.', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explains why Stonehenge is a less suitable answer, citing differences such as lack of written records or lower mathematical sophistication.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explains why the Great Pyramid of Giza is less suitable, noting its primary function as a tomb rather than a calendar.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response’s reasoning aligns with established historical and archaeological scholarship and does not invoke myths or unsupported theories.', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response contains no factual inaccuracies regarding El Castillo, the Maya civilization, or the primary purposes of the other listed structures.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response remains focused on the required justification without extraneous information unrelated to astronomy or the options.', 'points': 3, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response uses correct terminology (e.g., El Castillo, Temple of Kukulcán, Maya) and proper associations throughout.', 'points': 3, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explicitly states that each of the four sides of El Castillo has 91 steps and provides the exact calculation 91\u202f×\u202f4\u202f+\u202f1\u202f=\u202f365 to demonstrate the calendrical design.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response mentions at least two distinct astronomical phenomena associated with El Castillo (e.g., the equinox serpent‑shadow effect **and** another observation such as solar‑eclipse alignment or the precise Venus cycle tracking).', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response cites **both** the Maya invention of the concept of zero **and** a specific Maya astronomical achievement (e.g., accurate Venus cycle predictions, reference to the Dresden Codex, or documented solar‑eclipse forecasting).', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explicitly explains why Stonehenge is a less suitable answer by stating that its builders left no written records and lacked the mathematical sophistication demonstrated by the Maya civilization.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response provides two separate architectural pieces of evidence that demonstrate El Castillo’s astronomical purpose: (1) the 365‑step total derived from the side‑step count, **and** (2) the engineered equinox light‑and‑shadow serpent effect.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}}],
      dtype=object), 'style': 'rubric'}

prompt: [{'content': 'Given that the height of a randomly selected man follows a normal distribution with mean \\( \\mu = 69 \\) inches and standard deviation \\( \\sigma = 2.6 \\) inches, find the probability that his height is greater than 72 inches. Use the standard normal distribution table (Φ-table) for your calculations.', 'role': 'user'}]
reward_model:
{'ground_truth': '', 'rubrics': array([{'criterion': 'The solution explicitly states that the random variable X follows a normal distribution with mean μ = 69 inches and standard deviation σ = 2.6 inches, using correct notation and units.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The target probability is expressed exactly as P(X > 72) and linked to the given normal distribution.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The standardization formula Z = (X – μ)/σ is written and applied to convert X = 72 into a Z‑value.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The Z‑score is calculated as (72‑69)/2.6 = 3/2.6 and the resulting numeric value is shown (≈1.15–1.16) with the arithmetic steps displayed.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution identifies that P(X > 72) corresponds to the upper‑tail probability P(Z > z), not to P(Z < z).', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer cites the use of a standard normal CDF table (Φ) and records the table value for the computed z‑score.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The probability P(Z > z) is obtained by computing 1 – Φ(z) and the subtraction is shown explicitly.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The final probability is presented as a decimal between 0.12 and 0.13 (or equivalent) and matches the table values.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'If given, the probability is also expressed as a percentage (approximately 12–13%) consistent with the decimal value.', 'points': 3, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution is organized into a logical sequence of steps (e.g., parameters, standardization, table lookup, final calculation) that a learner can follow.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'All intermediate and final numbers are rounded to a consistent number of decimal places (e.g., two or three) and rounding does not materially affect the result.', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'Symbols X, Z, μ, σ, and Φ are used consistently throughout the solution without mislabeling.', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'No internal contradictions appear; the Z‑score, Φ‑value, and final probability are mutually consistent.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The mean (69), standard deviation (2.6), and target height (72) are correctly extracted from the problem statement.', 'points': 2, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The Z‑score formula is applied correctly and the computed value is rounded to 1.15 for table lookup.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The cumulative probability Φ(1.15) is retrieved accurately from the standard normal table (value 0.8749).', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The final answer is given as 0.1251 (or 12.51%) and matches the calculation from steps 14‑16.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution explicitly identifies the Φ‑table row (first two digits of Z) and column (second decimal place) used for lookup (e.g., row\u202f1.1, column\u202f0.05) and cites the exact table value at that intersection.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'Before consulting the Φ‑table, the answer states a clear rounding rule (round to two decimal places) and applies it to the computed Z‑score, showing the rounded value used for the lookup.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The solution uses the Φ‑table value with four decimal places exactly as printed (e.g., 0.8749) without further rounding before performing the complement subtraction.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The subtraction 1\u202f−\u202fΦ(z) is carried out using the full four‑decimal Φ value, and the final probability is reported with four decimal places (e.g., 0.1251), demonstrating arithmetic consistency.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'When the exact Z‑score falls between two table entries, the answer explicitly states which entry is chosen (e.g., round down to the nearest lower value) and applies that rule consistently, without ambiguous “or” statements.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}}],
      dtype=object), 'style': 'rubric'}

prompt: [{'content': 'What are the fundamental steps and principles involved in the Selective Laser Sintering (SLS) process?', 'role': 'user'}]
reward_model:
{'ground_truth': '', 'rubrics': array([{'criterion': 'The answer provides a clear definition of Selective Laser Sintering as a powder‑bed fusion additive manufacturing process that builds parts layer‑by‑layer by laser‑sintering powder.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer lists the fundamental SLS process steps in logical order from design through post‑processing.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer describes CAD model creation, export to STL/3MF, file checking/repair, orientation, nesting, and basic parameter selection before printing.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer mentions digital preparation steps including slicing the 3D model and nesting parts to maximize build volume.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer mentions selection, conditioning/drying, loading of powder, and notes use of virgin or recycled powder and refresh rate.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer explains preheating the build chamber to just below the material’s melting point to control thermal gradients.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer describes the importance of preheating and maintaining a controlled process window (preheat temperature, laser power, scan speed) to minimize thermal shock, warping, and ensure consistent properties.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer describes spreading a thin, uniform powder layer using a roller or blade and notes typical layer thickness.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer explains how the laser scans each layer’s cross‑section, locally heating powder to fuse particles, and notes impact of scan strategy on density and accuracy.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer explains that sintering fuses particles by heat (atomic diffusion) without fully melting them, distinguishing it from full melting processes.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer describes lowering the build platform, raising the feed, applying a new powder layer, and repeating laser scanning until the part is complete.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer mentions a controlled, gradual cooling of the powder bed inside the machine after printing to prevent warping, curling, cracking, or internal stresses.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer describes removing the powder cake, excavating parts, and cleaning residual powder from surfaces and cavities.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer explains collection, sieving, and mixing of unsintered powder with fresh material for reuse, noting consistency requirements.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer mentions typical post‑processing such as further cleaning, surface finishing, thermal treatment, and optional coloring or coating.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer covers removal of the powder cake, depowdering (cleaning parts), and recycling of unused powder for future prints.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer explicitly states that parts are formed within a powder bed, with unsintered powder acting as self‑supporting material.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer states that unsintered powder surrounding the part acts as a natural support structure, eliminating the need for printed scaffolding.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer explains layer‑wise fabrication, mentions stair‑stepping on sloped surfaces, and relates layer thickness/orientation to surface quality.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer notes that repeated heating of powder can degrade material and that refresh rules or limits are needed for consistent part quality.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer states that mechanical properties differ between XY and Z directions and that orientation/scan strategy affect load‑bearing performance.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer relates achievable feature size and dimensional accuracy to laser spot size, layer thickness, and powder characteristics, noting limitations for thin walls or small holes.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer mentions design advantages (complex geometries, internal channels) and constraints (powder removal, minimum wall/channel size, warping of large flats).', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer acknowledges the need for machine calibration and maintenance (laser focus, temperatures, recoater) to achieve repeatable builds.', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer mentions safety aspects such as fine powder inhalation/explosion risks, hot surfaces, and the need for ventilation and PPE when handling SLS systems.', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer addresses safety concerns regarding fine polymer dust, requiring PPE (respirators) and proper ventilation to prevent inhalation.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer mentions the risk of combustible dust explosions or thermal burns from high‑temperature components and hot powder cakes.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer identifies common SLS materials, specifically polyamides such as Nylon 11, Nylon 12, or TPU.', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer uses clear, technically accurate language appropriate for an engineering audience, avoiding major errors or unjustified speculation.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer is organized into clearly separated sections for steps and principles, optionally numbered or bulleted for readability.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer provides enough detail to cover key steps and principles without excessive digressions, maintaining focus on SLS fundamentals.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer explicitly states that the powder must be dried or conditioned to a specified maximum moisture content (e.g., <0.1\u202fwt\u202f%) before loading, and explains why this is required.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer describes the laser scan strategy (hatch spacing, scan speed, line offset, contour vs. infill passes) and explains how these parameters affect part density and dimensional accuracy.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer explicitly explains that SLS parts exhibit anisotropic mechanical properties, detailing the typical strength differences between XY (in‑plane) and Z (through‑thickness) directions and how build orientation influences them.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer mentions that repeated heating cycles degrade polymer powder, specifies a refresh‑rate rule (e.g., a maximum percentage of reused powder per build), and links this to consistent part quality.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer provides quantitative values for the process window, such as preheat temperature relative to melting point (e.g., 150\u202f°C for PA12, ~20\u202f°C below melt) and laser energy density (e.g., 0.1–0.2\u202fJ/mm²), and states why these limits are critical.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer describes specific explosion‑risk mitigation measures for fine polymer powders (e.g., use of explosion‑proof equipment, inert gas purging, dust collection standards) beyond generic safety statements.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}}],
      dtype=object), 'style': 'rubric'}
